name: Chicken Biryani
ingredients: Fresh coriander leaves and fried onions for garnishing
instructions: Wash the rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil or ghee in a large pot. Add cumin seeds, cardamom pods, cloves, cinnamon stick, and bay leaf. Sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and cook until golden brown.
Add ginger and garlic paste. Sauté for a minute.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften.
Add chicken pieces and cook until they are no longer pink.
Add red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add yogurt and garam masala. Stir and cook for a few minutes.
In a separate pot, bring water to a boil. Add the soaked and drained rice. Cook until the rice is 70-80% cooked. Drain the rice.
Layer the chicken mixture and partially cooked rice in the pot. Sprinkle some fresh coriander leaves and fried onions between the layers.
Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid. Place a tawa (griddle) under the pot to diffuse the heat. Cook on low heat for about 20-25 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld and the rice to fully cook.
Remove from heat and let it rest for 10-15 minutes before gently fluffing the biryani with a fork.
Serve hot with raita and enjoy!

name: Paneer Tikka
instructions: In a mixing bowl, combine yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, oil, red chili powder, turmeric powder, garam masala, cumin powder, and salt. Mix well to form a marinade.
Add paneer cubes, bell pepper chunks, and onion petals to the marinade. Coat them evenly with the marinade. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours.
Preheat the grill or oven to medium-high heat.
Thread the marinated paneer, bell pepper, and onion onto the soaked wooden skewers.
Place the skewers on the grill or in the oven, and cook for about 15-20 minutes, turning occasionally, until the paneer and vegetables are charred and cooked through.
Remove from the grill or oven and serve hot, garnished with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve the paneer tikka with mint chutney and lemon wedges.

name: Butter Chicken
instructions: Marinate the chicken pieces with yogurt, ginger paste, garlic paste, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Let it marinate for at least 1-2 hours.
Heat oil in a pan. Add marinated chicken pieces and cook until they are no longer pink. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add butter. Sauté chopped onions until golden brown.
Add tomato puree, cashew nut paste, garam masala, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add cooked chicken pieces to the masala. Mix well to coat the chicken with the sauce.
Add fenugreek leaves and heavy cream. Stir to combine.
Let the butter chicken simmer for 10-15 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and a drizzle of heavy cream.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or steamed rice.

name: Masala Dosa
ingredients: Oil or ghee for cooking dosas
instructions: Wash and soak rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 4-6 hours or overnight.
Grind them separately to a smooth batter using water as needed.
Mix the ground rice and urad dal batters together, add salt, and let it ferment overnight.
Heat a non-stick pan or a cast iron skillet. Grease it with a little oil or ghee.
Pour a ladleful of the dosa batter in the center and spread it in a circular motion to make a thin dosa.
Cook until the dosa turns golden and crisp. Place a portion of potato masala on one half of the dosa and fold it.
Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Chole Bhature
ingredients: 2 cups chickpeas (chole), soaked overnight and boiled
instructions: Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds, and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté until the raw smell disappears.
Add tomato puree, coriander powder, turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt. Cook until the oil separates.
Add boiled chickpeas and green chilies. Cook for a few minutes, adding water as needed.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
For Bhature, mix flour, yogurt, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Knead into a soft dough using water if needed. Let it rest for 2 hours.
Divide the dough into small balls. Roll them into discs and deep-fry in hot oil until they puff up and turn golden.
Serve hot chole with bhature, garnished with chopped onions and lemon wedges.

name: Samosa
instructions: In a bowl, mix flour, carom seeds, and salt. Add oil or ghee and rub it into the flour until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs.
Add water little by little and knead into a stiff dough. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for 20-30 minutes.
In a pan, heat oil. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add ginger paste and green chili paste. Sauté for a minute.
Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, garam masala, and amchur. Mix well.
Add boiled and diced potatoes and boiled peas. Stir-fry for a few minutes.
Add chopped coriander leaves and salt. Mix and let the filling cool.
Divide the dough into small balls. Roll each ball into a thin oval shape and cut it into halves.
Fold each half into a cone shape, fill with the potato-pea mixture, and seal the edges with water to form a triangular pocket.
Heat oil for deep frying. Gently slide the filled samosas into the hot oil and fry until golden brown and crispy.
Remove from the oil and drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with tamarind chutney or mint chutney.

name: Rogan Josh
ingredients: 500g mutton or lamb, cut into pieces
instructions: Heat oil in a pot. Add cardamom pods, cloves, cinnamon stick, and bay leaf. Sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and cook until they turn golden brown.
Add ginger and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add tomato puree and cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add red chili powder, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and fennel powder. Mix well.
Add yogurt and cook until the oil separates again.
Add mutton/lamb pieces and salt. Cook until they are browned.
Add enough water to cover the meat. Cover and simmer until the meat is tender.
Add garam masala and stir.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with steamed rice or naan.

name: Palak Paneer
instructions: Heat ghee or oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and asafoetida. Sauté until the cumin seeds splutter.
Add chopped onions and cook until they turn translucent.
Add ginger and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add tomato puree and cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add turmeric powder, garam masala, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add spinach puree and cook for a few minutes.
Add paneer cubes and fresh cream. Simmer for 5-10 minutes.
Garnish with a swirl of cream.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or rice.

name: Aloo Paratha
instructions: In a bowl, mix whole wheat flour with a pinch of salt. Add water and knead into a smooth dough. Cover and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
In another bowl, mix boiled and mashed potatoes with chopped green chilies, cumin seeds, carom seeds, turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, chopped coriander leaves, and salt.
Divide the dough and potato mixture into equal portions.
Take one portion of the dough and roll it into a small circle. Place a portion of the potato mixture in the center.
Gather the edges of the dough to encase the filling and roll it into a ball.
Flatten the stuffed ball and roll it gently into a round paratha.
Heat a griddle or tawa. Cook the paratha on both sides, applying ghee or oil, until golden brown spots appear.
Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or chutney.

name: Pani Puri
instructions: Blend mint leaves, coriander leaves, green chilies, and a little water to make a fine paste.
Mix tamarind pulp, mint-coriander paste, roasted cumin powder, black salt, regular salt, and water to make the pani (spiced water).
Make a hole in each puri and fill it with mashed potatoes, chickpeas, chopped onions, and tomatoes.
Dip the filled puri into the prepared pani and serve immediately.
Garnish with sev and enjoy!

name: Vada Pav
ingredients: Green chutney and dry garlic chutney for serving
instructions: For Potato Vada, heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, green chilies, ginger, asafoetida, and curry leaves.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, mashed potatoes, coriander leaves, and salt. Mix well and let it cool.
Divide the mixture into equal portions and shape them into round vadas.
For Batter, mix gram flour, turmeric powder, baking soda, and salt. Add water to make a thick batter.
Dip each vada into the batter and deep-fry until golden brown and crispy.
Slit the pav and spread green chutney and dry garlic chutney on one side.
Place a vada in the pav and serve hot.

name: Pav Bhaji
ingredients: 2 cups mixed vegetables (potatoes, cauliflower, peas, carrots), boiled and mashed
1/2 cup boiled and mashed green bell pepper (capsicum)
instructions: Heat butter in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté until the raw smell disappears.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, pav bhaji masala, and salt. Mix well.
Add boiled and mashed mixed vegetables, mashed bell pepper, and spinach. Mix and cook for a few minutes.
Using a masher, mash the mixture until well combined.
Simmer and let the bhaji cook on low heat for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Toast the pav with butter on a griddle and serve hot with the bhaji.

name: Dhokla
instructions: In a bowl, mix gram flour, semolina, yogurt, ginger paste, green chili paste, turmeric powder, lemon juice, and salt.
Add water gradually to make a smooth batter. Let it rest for 20-30 minutes.
Grease a dhokla steamer or a shallow dish.
Add Eno fruit salt to the batter and mix well. The batter will become frothy.
Pour the batter into the greased dish and steam for 15-20 minutes or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
For Tempering, heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, asafoetida, curry leaves, and green chilies. Sauté for a minute.
Pour the tempering over the steamed dhokla.
Cut the dhokla into pieces and garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve with green chutney or tamarind chutney.

name: Hyderabadi Dum Biryani
ingredients: 500g chicken or mutton, cut into pieces
A pinch of saffron strands soaked in milk
Fresh mint and coriander leaves for garnishing
instructions: Wash the rice thoroughly and soak it in water for 30 minutes. Drain and set aside.
Marinate the chicken or mutton with yogurt, ginger paste, garlic paste, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Let it marinate for at least 2 hours.
Heat oil or ghee in a large pot. Add cumin seeds, cardamom pods, cloves, cinnamon stick, and bay leaf. Sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and cook until golden brown.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften.
Add marinated chicken or mutton pieces and cook until they are no longer pink.
Add garam masala and mix well.
In a separate pot, bring water to a boil. Add the soaked and drained rice. Cook until the rice is 70-80% cooked. Drain the rice.
Layer the chicken or mutton mixture and partially cooked rice in the pot. Sprinkle saffron milk, mint, coriander leaves, and fried onions between the layers.
Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid and place a tawa (griddle) under it. Cook on low heat for about 20-25 minutes to allow flavors to meld and rice to fully cook.
Gently fluff the biryani with a fork and serve hot.

name: Prawn Curry
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent.
Add ginger paste and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add tomato puree and cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add red chili powder, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add cleaned prawns and cook for a few minutes until they turn pink.
Add coconut milk, curry leaves, and green chilies. Simmer for 5-10 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with steamed rice or roti.

name: Rajma Chawal
instructions: Pressure-cook soaked rajma until soft and tender. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil or ghee in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown.
Add ginger paste and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add tomato puree and cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add red chili powder, turmeric powder, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt. Mix well.
Add cooked rajma and yogurt. Simmer for 10-15 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot rajma curry with cooked basmati rice (chawal).

name: Aloo Gobi
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn translucent.
Add ginger paste and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add diced potatoes and cauliflower florets. Mix to coat them with the masala.
Cover and cook on low heat until the vegetables are tender, stirring occasionally.
Sprinkle garam masala and garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with roti or rice.

name: Chaat
instructions: In a serving bowl, layer boiled potatoes, chickpeas, chopped onions, tomatoes, and cucumber.
Drizzle tamarind chutney and green chutney over the ingredients.
Sprinkle roasted cumin powder, red chili powder, chaat masala, and black salt.
Top with sev and papdi.
Garnish with a dollop of yogurt and fresh mint leaves.
Serve immediately and enjoy the flavorful chaat!

name: Malai Kofta
ingredients: 2 tablespoons corn flour or besan (gram flour)
instructions: For Koftas, mix mashed potatoes, crumbled paneer, corn flour or besan, ginger paste, green chili paste, garam masala, chopped coriander leaves, and salt.
Shape the mixture into round kofta balls.
Heat oil for deep frying and fry the koftas until golden brown. Drain and set aside.
For Gravy, heat butter and oil in a pan. Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown.
Add ginger paste and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add tomato puree, cashew nut paste, red chili powder, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add garam masala and fresh cream. Mix well and simmer for a few minutes.
Blend the gravy to a smooth consistency using a hand blender or food processor.
To serve, place the koftas in a serving dish and pour the gravy over them.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or rice.

name: Mutton Curry
instructions: Heat oil or ghee in a pressure cooker. Add bay leaf, cloves, and cardamom.
Add chopped onions and sauté until they turn golden brown.
Add ginger paste and garlic paste. Sauté for a couple of minutes.
Add tomato puree and cook until the oil starts to separate from the masala.
Add red chili powder, turmeric powder, cumin powder, coriander powder, black pepper powder, cinnamon powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add mutton pieces and yogurt. Mix and sauté for a few minutes.
Add enough water to cover the mutton. Close the pressure cooker lid and cook until the mutton is tender.
Once the pressure is released, open the lid and add garam masala. Simmer for a few more minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or rice.

name: Jalebi
ingredients: Oil or ghee for deep frying
instructions: In a bowl, mix all-purpose flour, gram flour, yogurt, baking soda, and turmeric powder to make a smooth batter. Let it ferment for a few hours or overnight.
In a separate pot, make a sugar syrup by dissolving sugar in water. Bring it to a boil and let it simmer until it reaches a one-string consistency. Add cardamom powder and saffron strands.
Heat oil or ghee in a flat-bottomed pan for deep frying.
Pour the batter into a squeezable bottle or a piping bag with a small nozzle.
Squeeze the batter in a spiral shape into the hot oil. Fry until the jalebis are golden and crisp.
Remove the fried jalebis from the oil and immediately dip them in the warm sugar syrup.
Let the jalebis soak in the syrup for a minute or two, then remove and place them on a plate.
Serve hot or at room temperature.

name: Dahi Puri
ingredients: 1/2 cup boiled and sprouted moong beans
instructions: In each puri, add a spoonful of mashed potatoes and sprouted moong beans.
Top with chopped onions and tomatoes.
Drizzle tamarind chutney and green chutney over the puris.
Pour a little plain yogurt over each puri.
Sprinkle chaat masala, red chili powder, cumin powder, and salt.
Garnish with sev and fresh coriander leaves.
Serve immediately and enjoy the tangy and spicy dahi puri!

name: Pesarattu
ingredients: 1 cup whole green gram (moong dal), soaked for 4 hours
A handful of fresh coriander leaves
Chopped onions, grated carrot, and chopped green chilies for topping
instructions: Drain the soaked moong dal and grind it with green chilies, ginger, coriander leaves, cumin seeds, and salt. Add water as needed to make a smooth batter.
Heat a non-stick griddle or skillet and spread a ladleful of batter to make a thin dosa.
Drizzle oil or ghee around the edges and cook until the bottom turns golden and crispy.
Flip the dosa and cook the other side until it's cooked through.
Serve the pesarattu hot, topped with chopped onions, grated carrot, and chopped green chilies.
You can enjoy pesarattu with coconut chutney or ginger chutney.

name: Bhel Puri
ingredients: 1/4 cup nylon sev (thin gram flour noodles)
instructions: In a large mixing bowl, combine puffed rice, chopped onions, tomatoes, cucumber, potatoes, and coriander leaves.
Add tamarind chutney and green chutney as per your taste preference.
Sprinkle chaat masala, red chili powder, cumin powder, and salt.
Squeeze lemon juice over the mixture and toss everything well.
Add nylon sev and roasted peanuts. Mix again.
Serve immediately and enjoy the tangy and crunchy bhel puri!

name: Tandoori Roti
ingredients: Water (as needed to make the dough)
instructions: In a large mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour and salt.
Add water little by little and knead to form a soft and smooth dough.
Cover the dough with a damp cloth and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
Preheat a tandoor or grill to high heat.
Divide the dough into equal-sized balls and roll each ball into a flat round roti.
Place the roti on the hot tandoor or grill and cook until it puffs up and gets brown spots.
If using a grill, you can also cook the roti on a hot skillet or griddle.
Brush the cooked roti with butter or ghee for added flavor.
Serve the tandoori roti hot with your favorite Indian curries.

name: Gajar Ka Halwa
instructions: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add grated carrots and sauté on medium heat until they soften and the raw smell disappears.
Add milk and bring the mixture to a boil. Simmer on low heat, stirring occasionally, until the milk reduces and the carrots are cooked well.
Add sugar and continue to cook until the mixture thickens and starts to leave the sides of the pan.
Add chopped nuts, cardamom powder, and saffron strands. Mix well.
Cook for a few more minutes until the halwa reaches a desired consistency.
Garnish with raisins and serve hot, warm, or cold.

name: Phirni
ingredients: Chopped nuts and dried fruits for garnishing
instructions: Wash the rice and soak it in water for 30 minutes. Drain and grind it to a coarse paste.
Boil milk in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add the rice paste and stir well to avoid lumps.
Cook the mixture on low heat, stirring continuously, until it thickens and the rice is cooked.
Add sugar, cardamom powder, and saffron strands. Mix well and cook for a few more minutes.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Pour the phirni into serving bowls and garnish with chopped nuts and dried fruits.
Refrigerate until it's chilled and set.
Serve cold and enjoy the creamy and fragrant phirni!

name: Kulfi
instructions: In a heavy-bottomed pan, bring the milk to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the milk reduces to about half its original quantity.
Add sweetened condensed milk, sugar, cardamom powder, and saffron strands. Mix well and continue to cook until the mixture thickens further.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Pour the mixture into kulfi molds or small cups. Insert sticks into each mold.
Freeze the kulfi molds for at least 4-6 hours, or until they are completely set.
To serve, dip the molds briefly in warm water to loosen the kulfi. Gently unmold the kulfi onto serving plates.
Garnish with chopped nuts and enjoy the rich and creamy kulfi!

name: Rasmalai
instructions: Squeeze the syrup from the rasgullas and gently press them to flatten slightly.
In a wide pan, bring the milk to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the milk reduces to about half its original quantity.
Add sugar and cardamom powder to the milk. Mix well and continue to cook until the mixture thickens further.
Add the flattened rasgullas to the milk mixture. Let them simmer in the milk for a few minutes.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Garnish with chopped nuts and saffron strands.
Chill the rasmalai in the refrigerator for a few hours before serving.
Serve cold and enjoy the creamy and delightful rasmalai!

name: Misal Pav
ingredients: 2 cups mixed sprouts (moth beans, mung beans, black-eyed peas, etc.)
1/4 cup mixed farsan (mixture of sev, namkeen)
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and mustard seeds. Let them splutter.
Add minced garlic and sauté until fragrant.
Add chopped onions and cook until they turn golden brown.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften.
Add misal masala, red chili powder, turmeric powder, and salt. Mix well.
Add the mixed sprouts and a little water. Cover and simmer until the sprouts are cooked and the flavors meld.
In serving bowls, layer the sprouts mixture and top with mixed farsan.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve misal pav with pav bread rolls and enjoy the spicy and flavorful dish!
